metadata.title: Best Python Libraries for Every Python Developer | by Claire D. Costa | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Best Python Libraries for Every Python Developer
metadata.description: Python is an exceptionally popular programming language that is being used officially by a vast majority of organizations as their primary programming language. Similarly, a lot of developers, both…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: write-up on top Python projects on GitHub.

all_paragraphs: The joy of coding Python should be in seeing short, concise, readable classes that express a lot of action in a small amount of clear code — not in reams of trivial code that bores the reader to death.

Python is an exceptionally popular programming language that is being used officially by a vast majority of organizations as their primary programming language. Similarly, a lot of developers, both new and veteran alike, can vouch for Python’s effectiveness and efficiency. The reason why Python is favored a lot more than most other programming languages out there is, due to a couple of reasons.

The first is Python’s super easy syntax, leading to a much lower learning curve, the second being the versatility of the programming language itself, allowing developers to create a diverse range of applications. The third and probably the most prominent reason is Python’s exhaustive collection of libraries. In this article, we’ll expand more on the libraries part and shed some light on the best Python libraries that every developer should use today.
Check Out Some Interesting Python Articles —
Python is the most powerful language you can still read.- Pau Dubois

Python’s Package Index lists the number of currently available packages at over 270 thousand, putting Python in the fourth position among programming languages with the most readily available packages right behind Node.js, Java, and PHP. So, how does this affect you as a Python developer?

Well, this means there’s a good chance that whatever you’re trying to build, there’s already a package that can make the development easier for you. Below, we have listed our top picks for Python libraries that developers should use in their projects. Read on!
Google’s very own creation, TensorFlow, is among the leading Python libraries designed for carrying out high performance numerical and scientific calculations.

Primarily used for developing and training highly efficient Machine Learning and Deep Learning models, TensorFlow can also help you deploy these models to a host of platforms, such as a CPU, GPU, or a TPU(Tensor Processing Unit), with ease.
With TensorFlow, you have the freedom to use Google’s cloud platform or use your own device to work on your models.

Regardless of what you choose, you’ll get full access to TensorFlow’s rich collection of handy tools, APIs, and resources for not just creating your very own ML-powered applications, but also for experimenting with TensorFlow’s flexible architecture. You can get your hands on the library by running the command “pip install tensorflow”. We recommend visiting TensorFlow’s website to get an in-depth look at the library.

Requests is a part of a much larger collection of libraries by Kenneth Reitz, designed to make things simpler for humans, with “things” in our case referring to HTTP requests for Python. Being an HTTP library, requests aims to simplify the task of creating and sending HTTP requests to your Python applications.
By using the more intuitive JSON method offered by requests, you can absolutely forget about manually adding query strings to your URLs or form-encoding your PUT and POST data.
Some of the notable features of requests include — Connection timeouts, chunked HTTP requests, support for SOCKS proxy, keep-alive, connection pooling, and basic and digest authentication.

Due to its use in the development of web applications along with the features it offers, it has now become one of the most downloaded libraries. You should be able to add this package pretty easily to your development environment with the command “pip install requests”.

Similar to NumPy, Pandas is another popular high-performance Python library that is being widely used today for solving modern Data Science and Machine Learning problems. By offering developers access to flexible yet extremely responsive data structures for working with time series and structured data along with the stack of other vital features, Pandas aims to become the best data analysis tool available for solving real-world problems. A brief rundown of the features offered by Pandas include:
● An efficient DataFrame object for data manipulation
● Easy reshaping and pivoting of data sets
● Merging and joining of data sets
● Label-based data slicing, indexing, and subsetting
● Allows working with time-series data
● And other crucial tools for reading and writing data into multiple formats, even between in-memory data structures

In case you were looking for the best-in-class data analysis and manipulation tool, we highly recommend you give pandas a try. The installation is also fairly straightforward. Just run the command “pip install pandas”, and you should be ready to go.
NumPy is one of the most used libraries for tasks involving modern scientific computations and evolving yet powerful domains like Data Science and Machine Learning.
Wondering what exactly makes NumPy so popular among developers and data scientists today?

Well, the answer lies in the vast range of features that NumPy offers. The two vital benefits that NumPy has to offer is the support for powerful N-dimensional array objects and built-in tools for performing intensive mathematical as well as scientific calculations.
Other impressive features of NumPy include the use of an optimized C core for delivering high performance, interoperability with various computing platforms and hardware, and ease of use.

NumPy also plays well with many other visualization libraries, such as Matplotlib, Seaborn, and Plotly. If you want to give this library a try, you can do so by adding it to your system with the command “pip install numpy”.

PyTorch is another Python library that can let you work with projects involving Machine Learning, Deep Learning, and Neural Networks. Originally based on the high-performance Torch library, PyTorch offers speed, flexibility, and built-in support for GPU acceleration to the developers, offering you a big step-up compared to NumPy.
At its core, PyTorch consists of several vital modules that offer unique functionality, such as:

Today, PyTorch is being used more commonly to research, develop, and deploy applications that leverage advanced technologies like Computer Vision and Natural Language Processing. If needed, PyTorch can also pair well with other powerful libraries like NumPy, SciPy, and Cython.

And if it helps, apart from the usual Python interface, PyTorch also offers a C++ interface. If you’re interested in taking a look, you can give PyTorch a try with the following command “pip install torch”.
The creator of Keras, Francois Chollet defines the library as a powerful and flexible API for working with problems involving Deep Learning and Neural Networks.

Keras is designed to be simple while reducing the cognitive load, leading to lesser user interaction in most use cases. This feature makes Keras one of the coolest Python libraries for learning about Deep Neural Networks.
Being a core part of the TensorFlow ecosystem, the scalability provided by Keras lets you effortlessly scale your models to clusters of GPUs when needed.
Want to experiment with your models?

Keras offers plenty of firepower to help you quickly create model prototypes. Keras’ impressive deployment capabilities let you deploy your models on a variety of platforms, including web browsers, embedded devices, iOS, and Android devices. If all of this sounds good to you and you’re eager to give Keras a try, just run the following command “pip install Keras”.

Built on top of NumPy, Theano is essentially a library that excels at carrying out intensive mathematical and scientific calculations. With Theano, you can perform several types of operations on mathematical expressions involving complex multi-dimensional arrays, such as defining them, their optimization, and evaluation.

Key takeaways from Theano are its support for GPUs, speeding up the computations up to 140 times than what’s achievable with a CPU. There are also optimizations for speed and stability, integration with NumPy functions, and baked-in tools for finding and fixing bugs.

These are the robust capabilities that make Theano a suitable option to power through computationally-intensive scientific research tasks. But don’t let this give you an impression that Theano is only restricted to running large-scale computations, it is equally efficient for smaller workloads as well. The library can be downloaded easily from PyPI or with the following command “pip install Theano”.

Matplotlib is undoubtedly one of the most popular visualization libraries for Python. Being used by hundreds of companies and individuals, matplotlib lets you visualize your data in several different ways.
You can use it to create a wide variety of visualizations, including line plots, histograms, bar charts, pie charts, scatter plots, tables, and many other styles.

Matplotlib’s visualizations are not only restricted to static visualizations. If adding more depth and interaction to your visuals is what you want, you are free to go ahead and create interactive and animated visualizations as well. Of course, the publication-quality visuals created using matplotlib are fully customizable and can be exported seamlessly for other applications.

Python’s extendability also trickles down to matplotlib, allowing the library to be extended with additional features with extensions. If you want to take matplotlib out for a spin, you can do so by first adding it to your development environment with the command “pip install matplotlib”.

Before proceeding, let us make one thing clear. The SciPy ecosystem is a collection of several Python-based libraries, such as NumPy, Matplotlib, pandas, IPython, and SymPy, along with the SciPy library.

The libraries offered by the entire SciPy ecosystem have been curated to provide a convenient library stack that can take on intensive computations from domains like mathematics, science, and engineering, making things easier for data scientists and developers alike.

Talking about the library itself, SciPy depends on NumPy for providing access to fast N-dimensional array manipulations, efficient numerical routines for numerical integration, interpolation, statistics, linear algebra, and optimization.

The library is available for download with a simple command “pip install scipy”. Do keep in mind that although the SciPy stack consists of other libraries as well, you will need to install them separately.

Among the handful of other game development libraries available for Python, pygame is by far the best and the most popular of them all. pygame is built on top of the SDL(Simple DirectMedia Layer), which provides low-level access to computer hardware like keyboard, mouse, and graphics hardware like the GPU via OpenGL and Direct3D.

Talking about the library itself, this cross-platform library offers Python game developers tons of convenient features, including the fully modular, easy to use and optimized code, support for multi-core systems, and portability, to name a few.

Games built using pygame can deploy many of the industry-standard game development features, such as multichannel sound, detecting collisions, transformations, drawing support, vector math, pixel-array manipulation, and much more. If you want to start game development using Python, give pygame a try. You can install the library pretty easily with the command “pip install pygame”.

Web scraping is becoming more common by the day, thanks to the enormity of the data on the internet. Beautiful Soup is among the top libraries for scraping web pages. Apart from simply scraping content off web pages, Leonard’s web scraping library can do a lot more.

It has been designed to make information gathering a painless activity by allowing you to handle various aspects of the process, such as navigation, modification of the parse tree, and searching for the desired data.

Talking about the capabilities of the library, you could use the library to find specific bits of information, say, for example, find all the links from the data, find links that match to a specific URL, or even find the heading with the bold text and extract its data.
Installation of the library is straightforward, just run the command “pip install beautifulsoup4”, which downloads the latest v4 of the library that supports Python 3.
Web Scraping with BeautifulSoup and Requests —

Peewee is a small and effective ORM library written by Charles Leifer for Python developers. For those unfamiliar with an Object Relational Mapper, it’s essentially a mapping tool that lets you write SQL-like queries but by using the powerful object-oriented paradigms of your programming language.

Peewee allows developers to work with databases without necessarily getting into the intricacies of a relational database management system. The library supports many popular databases, such as SQLite, PostgreSQL, MySQL, and CockroachDB.
Of course, if you want to integrate a vendor-specific feature to your application, the library offers plenty of extensions, which we’re sure you’ll find pretty handy.

Peewee comes in two flavors, one supporting Python 2.7+ and the other supporting Python 3.4+. You can get your hands on the Peewee package either from PyPI or by running this simple command “pip install peewee” or “pip install peewee==2.1.6” for the Python 2 variant.
Pillow is based on the now-defunct PIL(Python Imaging Library) which offers all of the original functionality plus a couple of modern ones.

The Pillow library is robust enough to provide access to data stored in a few basic pixel formats. It also adds support for accessing a host of additional image file formats, such as PNG, PPM, TIFF, JPEG, GIF, and BMP. Although new file decoders can greatly help in expanding this format list. Some of the key features provided by the library include:
● Image blurring, contouring, smoothing, and edge finding
● Manipulating image sharpness, brightness, contrast, or color
If you’re building a Python application that in any way manipulates images, we strongly suggest using this library. You can get it with the following command “pip install Pillow”.
MoviePy is a compact yet practical Python library for video editing.
It offers plenty of options for video manipulation, including some basic ones like splitting the video, merging it, adding titles, and some audio manipulation.

There’s also a wide range of advanced options, such as tracking objects in video, drawing simple shapes, color gradients, generating subtitles, end credits, and much more. MoviePy will be the right fit for anyone looking to either code their own advanced video effects or to automate a major chunk of video processing tasks.

MoviePy also lets you automate the creation of gifs, and it even lets you create animations from the images generated by other Python libraries, say, Matplotlib, Scikit-images, Mayavi, and similar. If you have a video editing project in hand, why not give MoviePy a try with the command “pip install moviepy” and see for yourself what the library can do.

The Tkinter library is one of the most popular libraries for Python to create intuitive GUIs(Graphical User Interfaces). Tkinter provides the necessary Python interface to the Tk GUI toolkit, which is essentially a vast collection of visual elements, aka widgets that work on possibly every modern operating system.
It is one of the best places to start developing application GUI, as Tkinter offers developers the freedom and flexibility to create applications that support a pleasant and interactive GUI.
Apart from creating application interfaces, using Tkinter, Python developers can also create elemental 2D games, like Tic-Tac-Toe, quiz-based games, and the likes.

Tkinter comes pre-packaged with the Python 3.7 installer, but if your installer didn’t come with one, you can get it by running “sudo apt-get install python3-tk” for Linux, and for Windows or Mac, simply install ActivePython or Anaconda.
Top 10 Python GUI Frameworks —

Bottle is a small and lightweight WSGI micro framework that gives you just enough firepower to put together a fast yet robust web application in very little time. The framework has zero dependencies other than Python’s standard library and offers every core feature a web developer would ever need. Key highlights of Bottle include:
● Routing support for clean and dynamic URLs
● A baked-in template engine with out-of-the-box support for templates like mako, jinja2, and cheetah
● A handful of utilities to handle form data, file uploads, cookies, headers, and more
● And, a ready-to-use HTTP development server and support for other WSGI HTTP servers

Bottle supports Python 3, but for whatever reasons, if your web application is still using Python 2, or 2.7, to be specific, you should have zero issues using the framework. The package is available for download at PyPI, or you can add it to your machine with the command “pip install bottle”.

Python’s libraries are a vital part of its entire ecosystem, and there are thousands of them, some of which we discussed above. We understand that picking the right library from PyPI’s sea of libraries can be overwhelming for some, but this is why we penned down this article. We hope this article gives you an idea about some of the Python libraries available out there and what they do.

Once you’ve decided which library you’re going to use, we suggest visiting the documentation to see how it works. After getting a hang of these libraries, if you feel like you’re ready for a challenge, we recommend you check out our previous write-up on Python project ideas. If you simply want to see what people have been building with Python, check out our other write-up on top Python projects on GitHub.
Note: To eliminate problems of different kinds, I want to alert you to the fact this article represent just my personal opinion I want to share, and you possess every right to disagree with it.
If you have more suggestions, I’d love to hear about them.
I hope you’ve found this article useful! Below are some interesting readings hope you like them too-
